Although the 1998 Chicago Bulls had a highly dominant season, they still faced a few challenges along the way. 

One major challenge came from physical and mental fatigue, given that the team had won five championships in seven years leading up to the 1998 campaign. The grueling playoff schedule, coupled with the various injuries to key players during the course of the season, made it challenging for them to maintain their high level of play. 

Another obstacle was the fierce competition in the NBA, with other teams such as the Utah Jazz, New York Knicks, and the Indiana Pacers among others providing a tough test for the Bulls along the way. In particular, the Finals series against Utah Jazz represented a significant challenge, with the series tied at 2-2, and the Bulls needing to win two of the next three games, including two on the road, to clinch the championship. 

However, the Bulls were able to overcome these challenges with a mixture of talent, teamwork, and resilience, ultimately winning their sixth championship in eight years.
